source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The corrosion of Zircaloy in water reactors is dependent on the water chemistry of the primary coolant and the fast neutron flux.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Under standard pressurized water reactor (PWR) coolant conditions with hydrogen overpressure, resulting in a low oxygen content in the primary coolant, the fast neutron flux has no measurable influence on the corrosion rate.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Under oxygenated coolant conditions, typically for boiling water reactors (BWRs), the corrosion is enhanced by the fast neutron flux from the early beginning.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Three different types of oxide have been observed.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The dimensional behavior of Zircaloy under irradiation is governed by two processes: creep and growth.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The dimensional behavior of Zircaloy under irradiation is governed by two processes: creep and growth.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Creep is dependent on fast neutron flux and saturates with time.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Total growth results from irradiation growth, anisotropic creep, and mechanical interference.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Both in-pile creep and growth depend on the amount in recrystallization of the material.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Both in-pile creep and growth depend on the amount in recrystallization of the material.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The cladding tubes had been made from Zircaloy-2 [boiling water reactor (BWR)] and Zircaloy-4 [pressurized water reactor (PWR)] by different fabrication routes and by various manufacturers.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The cladding tubes had been made from Zircaloy-2 [boiling water reactor (BWR)] and Zircaloy-4 [pressurized water reactor (PWR)] by different fabrication routes and by various manufacturers.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Most of the material was in the stress relieved condition as specified by KWU.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: However, some experimental cladding tubes were fully or partially recrystallized

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: However, some experimental cladding tubes were fully or partially recrystallized

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: In contrast to the cladding tubes for the structural components, generally Zircaloy-4 had been chosen in both reactor systems. The condition of these materials was mainly fully recrystallized.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: the in-pile corrosion behavior of Zircaloy in water cooled reactors is markedly influenced by the oxygen content of the water.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: the corrosion in PWRs under low oxygen conditions is almost comparable to the out-pile behavior.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: the inpile corrosion was found to be enhanced by a factor of 2.4.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: Contact to stainless steel promotes the development of nodular corrosion [2,5].

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: Oxide nodules of up to $2 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ have been observed after long time exposure

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: break away occurs normally at $7 0 \ \mu \mathrm { { m } }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: only 30 percent of all lots form significant oxide nodules

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: the thickness of the oxide nodules decreases with increasing temperature

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2

evidence_span: stresses between 50 and $1 2 0 \mathrm { N } / \mathrm { m } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: the time exponent has found to be between 0.4 and 0.65 for three different types of cladding tubes

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2
evidence_span: The ovalization of unsupported cladding tubes of both unpressurized and prepressurized fuel rods

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk2

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Tubes with a high compressive tangential stress (closed tubes) show a larger length increase than the stress free open rods

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: relative length increase due to anisotropic creep was found to be $1 / _ { 1 0 }$ of the relative diameter decreases
specimen_state: fuel rods with anisotropic cladding and normal texture

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: mean of the length increase together with the standard deviation is shown as a function of fast neutron dose

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: The growth of fully annealed Zircaloy used for experimental fuel rods or channels showed a different dependence on the fast neutron dose. This type of material grows proportional to the square root of the neutron dose

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: By increasing the amount of recrystallization as determined by transmission electron microscopy, growth and cladding creep-down decrease
